section.title: Introduction
section.para: This chapter provides instructions for installing &sr;.
&sr; is officially compatible with two platforms: SGI and Linux. lists the recommended system requirements.
&recommendations;
describes the minimum software requirements for building &sr;.
&requirements;
On Linux systems (Mandrake 9 and Red Hat 8), &sr; binaries may be installed via RPM (Red Hat Package Manager). Alternatively, &sr; binaries may be built and installed from source code tarballs.
On SGI systems &sr; binaries must be built and installed from source code tarballs.
Be sure to read section after installing but before starting &sr;.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: You must have root privilages to install &sr;. Ask your system administrator to install &sr; if you don't have root privilages.
The following procedure installs &sr; in /usr/local/SCIRun/bin.

RPM installation consists of the following steps:
Downloading the &sr; RPM distribution and &sr;'s sample data sets.
Installing &sr; using the rpm command.
Installing &sr;'s sample data sets.
Installing &sr;'s documentation.

section.title: Downloading
section.para:
From SCI's software archive page download the following files:
Either SCIRun-x.x.x-mdk9.0.i586.rpm for Mandrake 9 systems or SCIRun-x.x.x-rh8.0.i386.rpm for Redhat 8 systems.
DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz too.
docs.x.x.x.tar.gz

section.title: Installing
section.para: Open a shell terminal (e.g. xterm) and enter the command su to become the root user (superuser). The su command will prompt you for root's password. If you do not have root access then ask your system administrator to install the RPM for you.

Now cd to the directory where &sr; was downloaded and type:
rpm -ivh SCIRun-x.x.x-mdk9.0.i586.rpm
for Mandrake 9 systems and
rpm -ivh SCIRun-x.x.x-rh8.0.i386.rpm
for Red Hat 8 systems. The RPM should take approximately one minute to install.
Type exit to leave the root account.
shows this process.

caption.para: RPM installation process. Assumes RPM file was downloaded to /tmp.

section.title: Installing &sr;'s Sample Data Sets
section.para: You may want to install the sample data sets in a location accessible to all &sr; users. The following procedure installs the sample data sets in the directory /usr/local. It assumes you can become the root user.

Use the su command to become the root user. Then Cd to the directory containing the compressed data sets tarball and type:
gunzip -c DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz | (cd /usr/local && tar xf -)
This will create /usr/local/&sr;Data, the sample data sets directory. Type exit to exit the root account.

section.title: Installing &sr;'s Documentation
section.para: You may want to install &sr;'s documentation in a location accessible to all &sr; users. The following procedure installs the documentation in the directory /usr/local

Use the su command to become the root user. Then Cd to the directory containing the compressed documentation tarball and type:
gunzip -c docs.x.x.x.tar.gz | (cd /usr/local && tar xf -)
This will create /usr/local/&sr;Docs, the &sr; documentation directory. Type exit to exit the root account.
Point your browser at /usr/local/&sr;Docs/doc/index.html to view &sr;'s online documentation.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Python (version 1.5.2 or later) and GNU make (version 3.79 or later) must be present before proceeding with the tarball installation.

Installation from tarballs consists of these steps:
Downloading (compressed) tarballs containing &sr; sources, packages, third party software, and sample data sets.
Unpacking the tarballs.
Building and installing third party software.
Building &sr;

note.para:
If you are building &sr; for the Itanium architecture you must use the GNU compiler collection (gcc). And you must set the values of the environment variables CFLAGS and CXXFFLAGS as follows before building &sr; and its third party libraries:
setenv CFLAGS fPIC setenv CXXFLAGS fPIC
for csh-type shells or
CFLAGS=fPIC CXXFLAGS=fPIC export CFLAGS CXXFLAGS
for sh-type shells,

listitem.para:
From SCI's software archive page obtain the following:
&sr; sources, &sr;.x.x.x.tar.gz
&sr; package sources, e.g. BioPSE.PKG.x.x.x.tar.gz
Third-party sources, Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.tar.gz
&sr; sample data sets, DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz
&sr; documentation, docs.x.x.x.tar.gz

Unpack the &sr; sources tarball in a directory of your choice:
gunzip -c &sr;.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create a directory called &sr;. Below we use the term &sr; when referring to this directory (ignoring its full pathname).

Unpack the compressed package tarballs into &sr;/src/Packages, for example:
gunzip -c BioPSE.PKG.x.x.x.tar.gz | (cd &sr;/src/Packages && tar xf -)
to unpack the BioPSE package.

Unpack the tarball containing sample datasets:
gunzip -c DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create the directory SCIRunData. You may want to move this directory to a location accessible to all &sr; users.

Unpack the third party tarball:
gunzip -c Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create the directory Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.

Unpack the documentation tarball:
gunzip -c docs.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create the directory &sr;Docs. You may want to move this directory to a location accessible to all &sr; users. Point your browser at &sr;Docs/doc/index.html to access &sr;'s online documentation.

note.title: Note
note.para: discusses a method for putting the downloaded &sr; sources under control of the CVS version control system. This is useful if you will be writing modules or other &sr; code. This is not a requirement for installing &sr; though!

section.title: Building Third Party Software
section.para: Third party software must be built before building &sr;. Follow these steps:

listitem.para:
cd to the third party software directory:
cd Thirdparty_install.x.x.x
Run the third party installation script.

The simplest execution of the script only requires a single argument:
python install dir
where dir is the directory under which the third-party software will be installed.

The installation script takes additional optional arguments as well:
python install dir bits jobs
where dir is the directory under which the third-party software will be installed, bits is either 32 or 64 and specifies one of 32 bit or 64 bit binaries, and jobs is the number of processes that make will use when building the software. For example:
python install /usr/local/&sr;/Third_Party 64 2
or
python install /usr/local/&sr;/Third_Party 32 1
When finished, the installation script will display the complete path of the third-party software installation directory—make note of this value.

section.para:
The complete path name of the third-party installation directory reflects the parameters given to the install script. This allows you to maintain multiple third-party installations for different operating systems and machine architectures. For example, on a Mandrake 9.0 Linux machine, the installation command:
python install /usr/local/&sr;/Third_Party
will create the installation under:
/usr/local/SCIRun/Third_Party/1.8/Linux/gcc-3.2-32bit

You may reinstall part or all of the third-party software by repeating your install command line exactly. The script will see that a previous installation exists at the specified location, at which point you will be asked to replace all or part of the installation. Just answer y or n when the script asks you which tarballs to reinstall. For each target that you said y to, the previous installation will be deleted, and a fresh one installed.

section.title: Building &sr;

listitem.para:
Run &sr;'s configure script. Do this from a sub-directory of &sr; (but not &sr;/src) as follows:
mkdir &sr;/dir cd &sr;/dir ../src/configure --with-thirdparty=third-party-dir \ --enable-package="package-name1 package-name2 …"
in which case &sr; will be built in the directory &sr;/dir (where dir is a directory name). Above, third-party-dir is replaced by the name of the third party software installation directory and "package-name1 package-name2 …" is replaced by a list of (previously downloaded and unpacked) package names , e.g. "BioPSE MatlabInterface". For example:
../src/configure \ --with-thirdparty=/usr/local/&sr;/Third_Party/1.8.0/Irix/CC-32bit \ --enable-package="BioPSE"

tip.para:
It is possible to build versions of &sr; for multiple machine architectures. For example, you may wish to build a Linux version and 32 bit and 64 bit Irix versions. Assuming the directory &sr; resides on a volume shared by all machines you may do this:
mkdir &sr;/linux mkdir &sr;/sgi32 mkdir &sr;/sgi64
Then, after logging onto the Linux machine:
cd &sr;/linux ../src/configure options
Then from the Irix machine(s):
cd &sr;/sgi32 ../src/configure options cd &sr;/sgi64 ../src/configure --enable-64bit options

listitem.para: There are many options to the configure command in addition to the --with-thirdparty and --enable-package options you have already seen. The configure --help command lists them all.

Run (GNU) make from the directory used previously when running configure (e.g. &sr;/linux, &sr;/sgi32, or &sr;/sgi64). Note that the configure directory will be called build_dir from now on.
cd build_dir make
Be sure that make invokes GNU make. GNU make may be named gmake or gnumake on your system.

For a multiprocessor system you can use GNU make's -j option to reduce the build time:
make -j N
where N is the number of processors available for use by make. Using this option on a multiprocessor machine will often significantly reduce the time to build &sr;.
Be sure to read section before starting &sr;.

section.para: After a successful build, build_dir will contain the scirun executable.

section.title: Preparing &sr;
section.para: Before starting &sr; you should initialize the environment variables SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR and SCIRUN_DATA. The following sections describe the purpose of the variables and how to initalize them.

section.title: Dynamic Compilation
section.para: Before starting &sr; you should be aware of a feature called Dynamic Compilation.

Dynamic compilition is a technique used by &sr; that discovers and generates code for the data types and algorithms used by modules in your networks. This is done at runtime and is done once for each new data type and algorithm encountered. This technique provides a number of benefits (not discussed here).

By default, code generated by dynamic compilation is stored in the directory build_dir/on-the-fly-libs for tarball installations and /usr/local/SCIRun/bin/on-the-fly-libs for rpm installations. The location of dynamically generated code can be changed by setting the value of the environment variable SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR to the desired directory, for example, in a shell terminal type:
mkdir ~/&sr;_otf
and then
SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR=~/&sr;_otf export SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR
for Bourne-like shells (ksh, bash, etc.) or
setenv SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR ~/&sr;_otf
for csh-like shells. Changing the location of the on-the-fly library directory provides a number of benefits described later.

The location of the on-the-fly directory can also be changed by setting the value of SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR in your .scirunrc file which is read by &sr; at startup. Your .scirunrc file would contain, for example:
SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR=$(HOME)/&sr;_otf
See the &sr; Users Guide for more information on the use of .scirunrc.

note.para: It is recommended that each &sr; user create an on-the-fly library directory in their home directory and set the value of SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR to point to this directory.

section.para:
Customizing the value of this variable for each &sr; user has the following benefits:
It allows multiple users to run the same instance of &sr; (at the same time) without worrying about dynamic compilation conflicts. For example, by specifying an on-the-fly-libs directory in their home directory, a user can run the same shared &sr; installed in /usr/local that another user is already running.
It allows a /usr/local installation of &sr; to be secure by not requiring that /usr/local/…/on-the-fly-libs be writable by all (which is considered a potential security risk).
It allows greater debugging and multiple build support by allowing the user to change dynamically compiled code locations between instances of &sr;.

section.title: Accessing Data Sets
section.para: The environment variables SCIRUN_DATA and SCIRUN_DATASET specify the complete path to a &sr; data set. SCIRUN_DATA specifies a directory which contains a collection of data set directories. SCIRUN_DATA is used in conjunction with SCIRUN_DATASET to specify the full path of a data set. SCIRUN_DATASET specifies a specific data set directory.

When working through &sr;'s tutorial you must set the value of SCIRUN_DATA to point to the sample data sets directory, SCIRunData:
export SCIRUN_DATA=/path/to/SCIRunData
or
setenv SCIRUN_DATA /path/to/SCIRunData
and SCIRUN_DATASET must point to one of the directories within SCIRunData, e.g. utahtorso:
export SCIRUN_DATASET=utahtorso
or
setenv SCIRUN_DATA utahtorso

section.title: Starting &sr;
section.para: If you installed &sr; from its rpm you can test its installation by typing /usr/local/SCIRun/bin/scirun (you may want to add /usr/local/SCIRun/bin to your PATH variable).
If you built &sr; from its source code tarballs then you can test its installation by cding to its build directory and typing ./scirun.
After starting &sr; you should see &sr;'s network editor window and the &sr; shell prompt.
If the window does not appear note any errors displayed in the &sr; console and see .
See the &sr; Users Guide for particulars on the use of &sr;.

section.title: Getting Help
section.para:
Subscribe to the &sr; users list. Use it to get answers to your installation and use questions. To subscribe send email to: majordomo@sci.utah.edu with the following in the body of the message (no subject):
subscribe scirun-users
To ask a question send email to: scirun-users@sci.utah.edu

Be sure to include a verbatim (cut and paste) copy of any errors displayed. Also include a short description of what you we're doing (running a network, building the tree, etc.) and which version of &sr; you have.
See also the Installation and User FAQs.
